description.plain:
UGK (an abbreviation for Underground Kingz) consisted of Bun B and the late Pimp C. They began their career in 1992, when they released their first EP, The Southern Way, as well as their first album, Too Hard To Swallow. In 1994, UGK released Super Tight, which broke the Billboard Hot 200.

In 1996, they released their Southern classic, Ridin' Dirty, which is their best album to date. With this new-found success, UGK recorded another album, Dirty Money, but was held up by Jive Records and failed to gain any sort of attention. Shortly after, in 2002, Pimp C was sent to jail for aggravated gun assault, and was in there until 2005. By the time Pimp C was released, UGK had plenty of buzz. Finally, after 6 years, UGK released Underground Kingz, a dual disc album. It reached number one on the Billboard charts and was a commercial and critical success. However, the success was cut short when Pimp C died in December 2007 due to an overdose of codeine/promethazine. Bun B completed their last project alone (though Pimp C recorded the majority of his part before he died). UGK 4 Life was released in 2009, marking the final UGK album.

description.plain:
The Underground Kingz (Bun B, Pimp C) and the Outkasts (André 3000 and Big Boi) unite in a classic track about the women in their lives. There are two stories about actually pimping out women for money, one cautionary tale about not getting girls pregnant, and one surprisingly sweet tale of marriage and blissful monogamy by André 3000.

The beat is the exact same as the one produced by the Three 6 Mafia members DJ Paul and Juicy J for J’s older brother Project Pat, first heard on the 2002 single “Choose U.”

https://genius.com/a/why-pimp-c-was-upset-with-andre-3000-s-international-player-s-anthem-verse



Listen to Bun B speak about this song’s process and experience in a 2018 Vlad TV interview.

songs.full_title: Murder by UGK
songs.title: Murder

description.plain:
Yet another great cut from UGK, if fairly typical in terms of themes. While the song holds its own by possessing an excellent beat and solid display from Pimp C, this song is most famous for its legendary verse provided by Bun B.

His lyricism, creativity and flow went off to reach whole new levels, and the verse is still used to measure up against Bun B’s new material. Seriously, describing it is almost completely pointless; it is the type of thing you need to hear to believe.

songs.full_title: Hi-Life by UGK (Ft. Smoke D)
songs.title: Hi-Life

description.plain:
“Hi-Life” is a song which explores the hardships of either the individual lives of Pimp C and Bun B or collective hardships of those in the ghetto.

Both verses are filled with despair and bleak imagery, describing what they’ve experienced and the extent of the struggle for them to improve their lives because of dilemmas and conflict they face.

They both strive to improve their lives, constantly working hard and doing their best to move up in life, with the ultimate motive of what’s portrayed as “unattainable”: the ‘Hi-Life’.

songs.full_title: Touched by UGK (Ft. Mr. 3-2)
songs.title: Touched

description.plain:
“Touched” is a song which explores and highlights the ways in which UGK and Mr. 3-2 are provoked and the implications and consequences of how they have been talked to or treated.

Specifically, each of the three artists teach those who are ignorant or oblivious to how you don’t treat them – if you don’t want to get beaten up or shot – by committing those acts, to show them what happens if the people are ‘out of line’.

songs.title_with_featured: 3 in the Mornin’ (Ft. Big Smokin' Mitch & C-Note)

description.plain:
“3 In the Mornin'” is a song which describes all the activities which go on in Bun B, Pimp C and Big Smokin' Mitch’s hometowns at that time.

Three in the morning signifies the time where hustlers start to get to work, staying ahead of their competition by making the first sale and earning more money. Each artist’s verse reflects this hustler mentality and provides an insight into what they have to do to survive and how relentless the life is.

songs.full_title: Ridin' Dirty by UGK
songs.title: Ridin’ Dirty

description.plain:
“Ridin' Dirty” is a song where Pimp C and Bun B talk about not only the police presence in their town being unnecessarily intrusive, especially when it comes to them being pulled over in their cars, but also the fact they’re ‘riding dirty’.

Riding dirty refers to driving in a car with illegal items—in this case, drugs and money they’ve earned from their sales.

They express their frustration about the times they have been pulled over when they’re just doing what they have to do to survive, with what they need to survive but the police have no understanding of why they have to live like that.

songs.title_with_featured: Da Game Been Good to Me

description.plain: Although some may argue that this song is not directed towards anyone in particular, Pimp even says so in the first verse, but for me, there’s only one pussy nigga that comes to mind…L!1' 7r0y. It’s obvious this song is directed towards him, but after L!1' 7r0y sued Scarface for dropping his name in the song G Code, Pimp knew better than to use any names. None the less, it’s glaringly obvious the song is about L!1 7r0y.

description.plain:
The twelfth track off of UGK’s comeback album (after a five-year hiatus), Dirty Money, heavily samples, in the beginning of their song, Barry White’s “Love Serenade”.

Here’s a comparison:

Take it Off by UGK
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q6iZgxukkPA

Love Serenade by Barry White
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qj1QRbhEmlU

Notice how Barry White also repeats throughout White’s song what Pimp C repeats exclusively for the chorus throughout Pimp C and Bun B’s song.

songs.full_title: It's Supposed to Bubble by UGK
songs.title: It’s Supposed to Bubble

description.plain:
“It’s Supposed To Bubble”, the classic ode to champagne off UGK’s 1994 sophomore album Super Tight, is not actually about champagne. Instead, it’s about smoking PCP-laced cigarettes, a trend that became popular in Texas in the early 1990s. Widely referred to as “fry,” the PCP at the tip of a cigarette “bubbles” when it burns, hence the clever title of the song.

The author of Bun B’s Rapper Coloring and Activity Book added:

I know that I knew that but I can’t say where exactly I heard it, or even if I heard it at all. I’ve spent a fair amount of time reading UGK lyrics so it all gets muddled together after a while. There’s a part in there where says a thing about “getting fried tonight,” so that’s probably the biggest hint. He also talks about selling drugs and both him and Pimp C mention Swisher Sweets, which for sure can be used to smoke angel dust. Also, Pimp references feeling like Goldie from The Mack, and he was a drug dealer in that movie. Most people are probably going to find it surprising because the chorus is so big and strong that it can dwarf the lyrics, but it’s all in there for you if you’re looking for it, probably.

description.plain: In this song, Bun B and Pimp C discuss a trend among young females in his area who pursue men based upon superficial attributes such as money and appearance, specifically the appearance of the cars they drive. Their attraction is based so much so on it that, as shown in the lyrics' explanation, it’s almost as if they want to have sex with the car itself, because the man himself is not factored into her choice.

songs.full_title: Good Stuff by UGK
songs.title: Good Stuff

description.plain:
“Good Stuff”, in contrast to the last song, is a celebration and description of the glamorous life: the life that comes after all the experiences they talked about in “Hi-Life”.

It’s sometimes described as the ‘A-side of the game’, (where you talk about success and the ‘good life’) if “Hi-Life” is considered the ‘B-side’ – what comes along with the good life and makes it possible. There is no success without first struggling – which is what UGK have highlighted, described and contrasted in these two songs.

songs.full_title: Use Me Up by UGK
songs.title: Use Me Up

description.plain:
“Use Me Up” can be interpreted as a companion piece to “Crampin My Style” from the same album. Both tracks are the only “love songs” from the album and are told from Pimp C and Bun B’s point of view, respectively. The interesting thing about these two tracks is the polarity between Bun and Pimp, in regards to how they view their relationships with women. Bun wants a one night stand and nothing more. He doesn’t want all the lovey-dovey hugging and cuddling, nor does he want the full-time duties of a boyfriend. As he so kindly puts it, he just wants to “Wham, bam, thank you ma'am”.

Pimp C, on the other hand, was blinded by what he thought was love. The girl he raps about has him doing everything for him: from dropping off her brother at school to giving her his credit card whenever she wants. All of this bidding goes against the rules he normally sets for himself when entering a relationship. He knows it’s not good for him, saying “I’m tripping and I know it cause I’m all nerved up”. Yet he continues the relationship. His homies even try to talk him out of it, rapping “Bun say I’m trippin out, and Byrd say I’m trippin, too”.

Although this particular version is heavily censored, compared to the version from their Southern Way EP, Pimp still gets his point across.

songs.full_title: Ain't That a Bitch (Ask Yourself) by UGK (Ft. Devin The Dude)
songs.title: Ain’t That a Bitch (Ask Yourself)
songs.title_with_featured: Ain't That a Bitch (Ask Yourself) (Ft. Devin The Dude)

description.plain:
This song is about situations Pimp C, Bun B, and Devin The Dude deem “a bitch” (unforunate). Pimp C and The Dude talk about trifling partners, while Bun B recites a letter the government sent UGK. This appeared on 2001’s Dirty Money.

It turns out, the biggest bitch of all is censorship—of which, this song is a victim. On all versions of the CD, you’d find the song’s version censors specific language, most noticeable in Pimp C’s verse—replacing “bitch” with “trick” (though, the chorus was left untouched). The dirty version later leaked—however, to this day, streaming the album provides the censored version, frustratingly. Rumors are that someone in the management of this album’s release did it themselves.

description.plain:
Feel Like I’m the One Who’s Doing Dope is a nightmarish story told through the eyes of unreliable narrator losing his mind. It pulls its title and samples a Scarface line from the classic Geto Boys song Mind Playing Tricks on Me:

Day by day it’s more impossible to cope
I feel like I’m the one that’s doin' dope

Rapped entirely by Pimp C, he weaves us his tale of being a crackhead, despite no memory of smoking.

songs.full_title: I'm So Bad by UGK
songs.title: I’m So Bad

description.plain:
This is a surprisingly crafty song for something so crass!

It takes a single line from an existing song (“I’m so bad, I can suck my own dick”) and expands it into its entire own song—and the concepts it explores in doing so go far beyond anything present in the original text.

When LL Cool J said the line, it was an isolated thought, just a throwaway declaration of his prowess in the middle of a stream of unrelated boasts. When Pimp C says it, he considers its implications. What if somebody really was so bad they could suck their own dick? How might it color their interactions with the world? What are its psychological ramifications?
